intro: Conoclinium dissectum, commonly known as the Mexican honeysuckle, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its showy, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant typically grows as a vigorous perennial, often reaching heights of 3 to 6 feet, with lance-shaped, deeply lobed leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early autumn, producing a fragrant, nectar-rich display. Conoclinium dissectum is well-suited for gardens and wildlife habitats due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
